title: Understanding the Problem
text: The domain of a function refers to all the possible values that you can input into the function without causing any mathematical problems, like taking the square root of a negative number.

title: Identifying the Function
text: You need to recognize what kind of function you are dealing with. Here, we have $$f(x)=3-\sqrt{6-2x}$$. Notice the square root $$sqrt$$ function. This helps us determine the domain.

title: Considering Square Roots
text: Remember, the square root of a number needs to be zero or positive (it can't be negative). Therefore, what is inside the square root must be greater than or equal to zero: $$6-2x$$ $$ \geq $$ $$0$$.

title: Solving the Inequality
text: Solve the inequality $$6-2x$$ $$ \geq $$ $$0$$ to find which values of $$x$$ will work. This will tell us the domain.

title: Calculate the Solution
text: Rearrange the inequality $$6-2x \geq 0$$ to find $$x$$. Add $$2x$$ to both sides first. You have $$6 \geq 2x$$. Then divide by $$2$$.

title: What is Interval Notation?
text: Interval notation is a way of writing the set of solutions for an inequality. Use brackets: '[' or ']' for inclusive bounds and '(' or ')' for exclusive bounds.\nFor $$x \leq 3$$, the interval is $$(-\infty,3]$$.
